title: 110_s2498
content: The Act may be cited as the "Santa Fe 400th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 2007". It includes findings related to the commemoration. Santa Fe, New Mexico, a historic city with diverse cultures, was elevated to a capital city in 1610. The Palace of the Governors, dating back to the 17th century, is the oldest continuously used public building in the US. La Fiesta de Santa Fe, a cultural celebration since 1692, attracts tourists and locals. Santa Fe's location at the intersection of three important trails facilitated trade and travel. Santa Fe, New Mexico, a historic city with diverse cultures, served as a hub for trade and travel over the Santa Fe Trail to and from Missouri, California, and Mexico City. Commerce on the trail boosted the economy of the American West during the early 19th century recession. Today, Santa Fe is known for its multicultural citizenry, world-class art market, and hosts various art and cultural markets year-round. New Mexico is home to the oldest continuously inhabited indigenous communities in North America, including Acoma Pueblo. The indigenous communities residing in New Mexico include Acoma Pueblo, Alamo Navajo Chapter, Canoncito Navajo Chapter, Cochiti Pueblo, Isleta Pueblo, Jemez Pueblo, Jicarilla Apache Tribe, Laguna Pueblo, Mescalero Apache Tribe, Nambe Pueblo, Picuris Pueblo, Pojoaque Pueblo, Ramah Navaho Chapter, San Felipe Pueblo, San Ildefonso Pueblo, San Juan Pueblo, Sandia Pueblo, Santa Ana Pueblo, Santa Clara Pueblo, Santo Domingo Pueblo, Taos Pueblo, and Tesuque Pueblo. The Pueblo Revolt of 1680 was one of the first American revolutions, where Pueblo people ousted Spanish colonists from New Mexico. Santa Fe has long attracted tourists, artists, and writers, with the classic novel Ben Hur partially written by Governor Lew Wallace in the Palace of the Governors. A commemorative coin aims to promote understanding and appreciation of New Mexico's history, culture, and its significance in the history of the United States and the world. The commemorative coin aims to promote understanding and appreciation of New Mexico's history, culture, and significance in the history of the United States and the world. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue limited quantities of $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Gold for minting will be obtained from specified sources. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting coins from domestic sources and silver only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the settlement of Santa Fe, New Mexico, with specific inscriptions required. The design will be chosen by the Secretary and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single US Mint facility during 2010. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount, and bulk sales will also be offered at a discount. All sales will include a surcharge. Sales of coins minted under this Act will include a surcharge of $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for the Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges from coin sales. The Secretary shall distribute surcharges from coin sales to the Santa Fe 400th Anniversary Committee and the Secretary of the Department of the Interior for various purposes. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit entities involved in distributing funds for educational programs, improving infrastructure, archaeological research, and other activities related to the 400th anniversary of Santa Fe. SEC. 9 of the Act focuses on financial assurances for minting and issuing coins, ensuring no net cost to the government. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantees provided to the Secretary.
